readme: This content pack explores the geopolitical shift as India and the Global South challenge the dominance of European digital structures. It poses the critical question: will SAIX remain a closed European fortress or evolve into the backbone of a new, non-aligned digital world?

items.headline: The New Delhi Declaration: A Challenge to Digital Colonialism
items.body: In a landmark summit, representatives from India, Brazil, and the African Union have proposed a 'Unified South Protocol' (USP). The declaration explicitly critiques the Euro-centric architecture of current SAIX nodes, labeling them 'legacy structures of a fading hegemony.' The USP aims to create a parallel data infrastructure that prioritizes local data sovereignty and rejects the mandatory adherence to Brussels-mandated ethics filters, which they claim are culturally biased and economically stifling.
items.flavor: The map of the internet is being redrawn, and the ink is being poured in the South.

items.headline: Strategic Crossroads: The Fortress Dilemma
items.body: Confidential internal analysis suggests that SAIX's current 'Fortress Europe' stance is increasingly untenable. While our encryption standards are the gold standard for the EU, India's recent Bharath-Mesh launch has attracted 40% of our former tier-two partners. We face a binary choice: either we maintain our strict continental isolation to preserve 'purity' of the stack, or we become the neutral gateway for the non-aligned digital world. If we choose the former, we risk irrelevance; if we choose the latter, we risk the wrath of the Euro-Commission.
items.flavor: A wall is both a shield and a cage.

items.headline: #DigitalBandung: The Decolonized Stack
items.body: Thread (1/6): Why are we still waiting for European keys to unlock our own data? (2/6) The Bangalore cluster just achieved 0.4ms latency without a single Brussels-based hop. (3/6) Digital sovereignty isn't just a buzzword, it's about who owns the logic. (4/6) SAIX can be our ally or our master. We choose the former. (5/6) The non-aligned movement is moving to the cloud. (6/6) Are you watching, SAIX? Or are you too busy polishing your borders?
items.flavor: The future doesn't need a visa.
